text: For people complaining, here’s some examples of what DEIA actually is. Trainings to prevent sexual harassment in the workplace are part of DEI initiatives. Pay transparency laws are the result of DEI initiatives. Requiring wheel chair ramps and closed … See more

My favorite way to relax is when Costco doesn’t use a company like AT&T that has zero customer service and cannot even answer questions or call you back. I have the receipt email showing that I purchased it and AT&T says I’ve never purchased. It says they’ll put notes in the file. nobody calls me, and there are no notes, so I ask what happened and they said they could sell me $100 cruise line it didn’t work bottom line is I use the phone three times and a few text it cost me $550 and Costco AT&T want to talk to me about it Costco says they’ll have somebody call me. AT&T calls me literally 14 times this person has called And never ever told me a time to call back or when I answer it hangs up this is a joke. Do not get your phone at Costco from AT&T.

I’m not sure I understand your comment. DEI policies help address inequalities caused by bias (both conscious and unconscious). That they are standing behind their DEI policies helps explain why Costco is not sued nearly as often by its former employees as other large companies, at least this is the case in California. (I handle discrimination, harassment, retaliation and other types of employee claims, on behalf of employees.)

I do love that you believe there are so many attorneys that would NOT sue a company based on what you consider just a political belief, and that this is more likely than the simple fact that there is nothing to sue over when they follow the laws…

DEI policies help employers follow the law. A lot of policies have this as a purpose… specifically, they help employees address whether there may be policies or procedures in place that have unconscious biases (or conscious ones) that may have prevented diversity and inclusion.
